Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence among its believers have varied significantly across political affiliations, with a widening partisan divide in recent years. Conservatives and Republicans are far more likely than liberals and Democrats to associate Islam with violence. Currently, 68% of Republicans say Islam is more likely to encourage violence, a historical high and largely unchanged since 2014. In contrast, only 30% of Democrats hold this view, down from 42% in 2014 [8][12]. 

![Republicans associate violence with Islam more than Democrats](image2)  

This partisan gap aligns with broader trends in attitudes toward terrorism and government efforts to combat it. Democrats are more likely to say the government is doing at least fairly well in reducing the terrorist threat (64%), though this is a decline from 85% in early 2015. Republicans, however, are highly critical, with only 27% approving of the government’s efforts, down from 63% at the start of the year [5].  

![Government handling of terrorism is viewed more negatively by Republicans](image5)  

These differing perceptions of Islam and terrorism also intersect with views on whether Muslims should face additional scrutiny due to their religion. While 61% of Americans overall oppose such scrutiny, conservative Republicans are the only group where a majority (57%) supports it. In contrast, 87% of liberal Democrats oppose increased scrutiny for Muslims [1][4].  

![Conservative Republicans support increased scrutiny of Muslims](image4)  

In summary, Republicans are far more likely to associate Islam with violence and to support increased scrutiny of Muslims, while Democrats increasingly reject both notions. These views are linked to broader dissatisfaction with government efforts to combat terrorism, particularly among Republicans. The partisan divide on these issues has reached a historical high, reflecting deeper political polarization.

Perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have shifted significantly over time, particularly along political lines. Among Republicans, the belief that Islam encourages violence more than other religions has risen sharply, from 33% in 2002 to 68% in 2015, marking a historical high [1][7][9]. ![Republicans' belief that Islam encourages violence has risen sharply over time](image1). Conversely, Democrats have seen a decline in this belief, from 42% in September 2014 to 30% in December 2015, reflecting a 12-point drop [7][9]. Independents remain split, with 45% supporting the view that Islam encourages violence, a slight increase from earlier years [2].

Public opinion on party capabilities in handling terrorism shows a notable preference for the Republican Party, with 46% believing Republicans can better address the terrorist threat compared to 34% favoring Democrats [8]. ![Republicans are perceived as stronger on handling terrorism](image5). This aligns with the growing partisan divide on Islam and violence, where Republicans increasingly associate Islam with violence, while Democrats and Independents move in the opposite direction [7].

Overall, the widening ideological gap on Islam’s perceived violence mirrors the public’s trust in Republicans over Democrats regarding terrorism, highlighting a persistent alignment between attitudes on religion and political competence.

Perceptions of scrutiny of Muslims in the U.S. vary significantly across political and demographic groups, and these views are closely tied to the perceived importance of terrorism as a national issue. 

Among political affiliations, **Conservative Republicans** are the only group where a majority (57%) supports greater scrutiny of Muslims solely because of their religion, while 35% oppose it. In contrast, **Liberal Democrats** overwhelmingly reject this idea (87% oppose, 12% support) [3][12]. ![Conservative Republicans are the only group where a majority supports greater scrutiny of Muslims.](image5) Similarly, **moderate and liberal Republicans** (59%) and **conservative/moderate Democrats** (67%) also oppose additional scrutiny, though to a lesser extent [3][5].

Demographically, **younger individuals** (18-29) are the most opposed to scrutinizing Muslims based on religion (80% oppose), while **older adults** (50+) are more divided (50% support, 41% oppose) [10][11]. ![Younger individuals are the most opposed to scrutinizing Muslims based on religion.](image1) Additionally, **non-white groups** (74% Black, 66% Hispanic) are more likely to reject scrutiny compared to **whites** (57%) [4].

This divergence in attitudes correlates with the perceived importance of terrorism as a national issue. **Republicans** prioritize terrorism and national security far more than **Democrats** and **Independents**, with 41% of Republicans citing these issues as the most important problem facing the nation, compared to 28% of Independents and 23% of Democrats [6]. ![Republicans prioritize terrorism and national security more than Democrats and Independents.](image6) This heightened focus on terrorism among Republicans may contribute to their greater support for scrutinizing Muslims. Conversely, groups like Liberal Democrats, who are less likely to view terrorism as a top issue, are also more inclined to oppose religious-based scrutiny.

In summary, perceptions of scrutinizing Muslims are deeply polarized along political and demographic lines, with groups prioritizing terrorism more likely to support such measures, while those less focused on terrorism generally oppose it.

Perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat it have shifted significantly over time, with notable differences across demographic and political groups. Public concern about terrorism has risen sharply, with **29%** of Americans now citing terrorism (**18%**), national security (**8%**), or ISIS (**7%**) as the most important problem facing the country, the highest since February 2003 [10]. This marks a significant increase from a year ago, when only **4%** mentioned these issues [10].

![The table presents survey data showing the rise in terrorism concerns from December 2014 to December 2015](image8)

Assessments of the government’s efforts to reduce the terrorist threat are at their lowest since September 2001. For the first time, more Americans believe the government is doing "not too well" or "not at all well" (**52%**) than "very well" or "fairly well" (**46%**), a **26-point drop** since January [4]. Positive ratings have declined across all political groups, with Democrats, Independents, and Republicans all expressing more negative views compared to early 2015 [12].

![The table shows declining approval of government efforts to combat terrorism across demographic and political groups](image3)

Older and less educated individuals are more critical of the government’s performance. Among those aged 50 and older, **57%** believe the government is not doing well, compared to **46%** of younger adults (18-29) [11]. Similarly, those with a postgraduate degree are more positive (**58%** say the government is doing well) than those with less education (**44%**) [3].

Partisan divides are stark. Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security, with **41%** mentioning these issues, compared to **28%** of Independents and **23%** of Democrats [6]. However, Democrats are the only group where a majority (**64%**) still rate the government’s efforts positively, though this is down from **85%** in January [12].

![The table highlights partisan differences in prioritizing terrorism and national security](image4)

Public opinion on anti-terror policies has also shifted. **56%** now believe these policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, up seven points since the start of the year, while **28%** think they have gone too far in restricting civil liberties [8]. This reflects a growing concern about security over civil liberties.

![The line graph illustrates the shift in public opinion on anti-terror policies from 2004 to 2015](image7)

In summary, perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat it have become more negative over time, with significant differences based on age, education, and political affiliation. Public concern about terrorism has surged, while confidence in the government’s ability to address the threat has declined.

Republicans and Democrats exhibit significant differences in their views on terrorism and economic issues. On terrorism, Republicans are more likely to prioritize it as a top concern, with 41% mentioning terrorism, defense issues, and national security or ISIS, compared to 23% of Democrats [9]. Additionally, Republicans are more inclined to believe that Islam is more likely to encourage violence (68%) than Democrats (30%) [2], and they overwhelmingly support using overwhelming military force to defeat terrorism (72%) compared to Democrats (27%) [4]. Republicans also express greater concern that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough (71%) [3].

![71% of Republicans say anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough](image3)

On economic issues, Democrats are more likely to cite dissatisfaction with the government or partisan gridlock (8%) than Republicans (2%) [8]. While the economy remains a concern for both parties, its prioritization has declined among Republicans and Democrats over time, with a net decrease in mentions of economic issues from 34% to 23% [8]. This shift reflects a broader trend where foreign and terrorism-related concerns have risen sharply, particularly among Republicans.

![Terrorism concerns increased from 1% to 18% between 2014 and 2015](image8)

In summary, Republicans are more focused on terrorism and national security, while Democrats are more concerned with economic issues and government dysfunction.

Views on the importance of terrorism vary significantly among political affiliations, with Republicans expressing the highest concern. According to the survey, 41% of Republicans mention terrorism, defense issues, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem facing the nation, compared to 28% of independents and 23% of Democrats [6]. This partisan divide is reflected in the perception of government efforts to address the terrorist threat. While Democrats are the most likely to rate the government’s performance positively at 64%, only 27% of Republicans say the government is doing very or fairly well, marking a sharp decline from 63% at the beginning of the year [5]. Conservatives within the Republican Party are particularly critical, with only 18% now giving the government positive ratings, down from 59% in January [7]. 

![Political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of terrorism's importance and government performance](image7)

The data also reveals that Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and related issues compared to Democrats, who focus more on partisan gridlock and division [10]. This disparity in priorities aligns with the broader trend of declining approval of government efforts across all political groups. For instance, positive ratings among independents have dropped by 25 points, from 69% to 44% [5]. The overall trend suggests that while terrorism remains a central concern for Republicans, dissatisfaction with the government’s handling of the issue has grown across the political spectrum. 

![Public opinion on terrorism and government efforts has shifted over time](image4)

In summary, while terrorism is a higher priority for Republicans, all political groups have become more critical of the government’s performance in addressing the threat, with Republicans experiencing the sharpest decline in approval.

Independent voters’ views on government regulation and economic fairness often fall between those of Democrats and Republicans, reflecting their more moderate or varied political alignment. Here’s a breakdown of their perspectives:

On **government regulation**, independents are generally split. The data shows that 48% of independents believe government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while 43% think it does more harm than good [3]. This contrasts with Democrats, who heavily favor regulation (65% say it’s necessary), and Republicans, who are more skeptical (61% say it does more harm) [3].

Regarding **economic fairness**, 66% of independents believe the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, while 30% think it is generally fair [image2]. This aligns more closely with Democrats, of whom 85% think the system unfairly favors powerful interests, than with Republicans, of whom only 29% share this view [12]. Interestingly, Republican-leaning independents are more divided on this issue, with 46% saying the system unfairly favors powerful interests and 49% considering it fair [12].

![Independents lean towards viewing the economic system as unfair, with 66% saying it favors powerful interests](image2)

In terms of **government size**, independents are nearly evenly split: 47% prefer a smaller government providing fewer services, while 44% favor a bigger government with more services [3]. This contrasts sharply with Republicans, who overwhelmingly prefer smaller government (74%), and Democrats, who largely favor bigger government (73%) [3].

![Independents are divided on government size, with 47% preferring smaller government and 44% favoring bigger government](image3)

Overall, independents tend to occupy a middle ground between the more polarized positions of Democrats and Republicans on these issues, reflecting their diverse and less partisan perspectives.

Over the past two decades, unfavorable views towards both major U.S. political parties among independents have shown significant shifts, with increasing polarization and varying trends among subgroups.  

In 1994, only 6% of independents held unfavorable opinions of both parties, but this figure rose to 12% by 2018 [image7]. This trend reflects a broader societal polarization, where individuals increasingly view the opposing party negatively. However, the share of independents with unfavorable views of both parties peaked at 36% in 2015 before declining to 28% in recent years [8].  

Breaking down independents into subgroups, those who lean toward a party exhibit stronger partisan biases. For example, 24% of Republican-leaning independents and 27% of Democratic-leaning independents hold unfavorable views of both parties, which is lower than the 37% of independents with no political lean who view both parties negatively [image5]. This suggests that while leaners are more aligned with their respective parties in terms of favorability, those without a lean are more likely to distrust both parties.  

Furthermore, the intensity of negative views has surged among leaners. The share of Democratic-leaning independents with a *very* unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party more than quadrupled from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018. Similarly, Republican-leaning independents with very unfavorable views of the Democratic Party rose from 15% to 39% over the same period [5].  

![Independents with unfavorable views of both parties rose from 6% in 1994 to 12% in 2018](image7)  
![The share of independents with unfavorable views of both parties peaked at 36% in 2015 before declining to 28%](image8)  

In summary, unfavorable views of both parties among independents have increased since 1994 but declined in recent years, with those leaning toward a party showing less negativity than those without a lean, and the intensity of dislike for the opposing party rising sharply among leaners.

Over the past two decades, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have increased significantly across all political affiliations, reflecting growing polarization. Among Democrats, unfavorable views of the Republican Party rose from 59% in 1994 to 88% in 2018, while Republican-leaning independents’ unfavorable views of the Democratic Party increased from 64% to 81% during the same period [6]. Similarly, Democratic-leaning independents’ unfavorable views of the Republican Party surged from 48% to 84% [6]. Independents as a whole also saw a rise in unfavorable views, from 24% in 1994 to 56% in 2018 [6].

![Increase in unfavorable views of opposing parties from 1994 to 2018](image6)

Currently, independents who do not lean toward either party are the most likely to have unfavorable opinions of both parties (37%) [12]. Another 22% of these independents hold favorable views of both parties, while only 11% view the Democratic Party favorably and 9% view the Republican Party favorably [12]. This contrasts with partisans, who are more likely to view their own party favorably while holding negative views of the opposing party.

![Current levels of favorability and unfavorability among independents](image7)

Overall, the data shows a trend of increasing polarization, with more people viewing the opposing party unfavorably, while independents without party leanings are more likely to hold unfavorable views of both parties.

Republicans and Democrats hold significantly different views on China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on U.S.-China relations. Republicans are far more critical of China’s response, with 82% saying China has done a bad job, compared to 54% of Democrats. Additionally, 61% of Republicans believe China has done a *very* bad job, while only 30% of Democrats share this sentiment [9]. ![Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the outbreak](image1)

The perception of China’s role in the global spread of the virus also varies by party. Around 73% of Republicans think China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to just 38% of Democrats [10]. ![Republicans are more likely to blame China for the virus's global spread](image2)

These differing views influence their stance on U.S.-China relations. A majority of Republicans (71%) believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for the outbreak, even if it worsens economic relations, while only 37% of Democrats agree with this approach [11]. ![Republicans favor holding China responsible over maintaining strong relations](image5)

Overall, Republicans are more likely to criticize China’s handling of the pandemic and advocate for tougher policies, while Democrats are less critical and more inclined to prioritize maintaining strong U.S.-China relations.

Republicans and Democrats have significantly different perceptions of China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, and these views have evolved over time. According to the survey conducted in 2020, **82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** believe China has done a bad job dealing with the outbreak, compared to **54% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** [4]. Additionally, Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to say China has done a *very* bad job (61% vs. 30%) [4]. 

![Republicans are more critical of China's COVID-19 response than Democrats](image8)

Over time, these perceptions have grown more negative across both parties, but the increase is more pronounced among Republicans. In 2011, **39% of Republicans** had unfavorable views of China, which surged to **83% by 2020**. Among Democrats, unfavorable views rose from **34% in 2005 to 68% in 2020** [image4]. This trend aligns with broader criticisms of China’s role in the pandemic, as **73% of Republicans** believe China’s early handling of the virus contributed a great deal to its global spread, compared to **38% of Democrats** [2].

![Perceptions of China's role in the pandemic have become more critical over time](image4)

In summary, Republicans are far more critical of China’s handling of COVID-19 than Democrats, and this criticism has intensified significantly over the years across both political groups.

Americans hold largely negative views of China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak, with around two-thirds (64%) stating that China did a bad job handling the crisis, including 43% who believe it did a very bad job [4]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, with 82% criticizing China’s handling of the pandemic compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [11]. ![Criticism of China's handling of the pandemic varies by political affiliation](image2)

Partisan differences extend to perceptions of China’s responsibility for the global spread of the virus. Around 73% of Republicans believe China’s early handling contributed a great deal to the pandemic’s spread, while only 38% of Democrats share this view [9]. Older Americans are also more likely to blame China, with 73% of those aged 50 and older finding fault [11]. ![Republicans are more critical of China's role in the pandemic](image5)

When it comes to U.S.-China relations, half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the outbreak, even if it worsens economic ties, while 38% prioritize maintaining strong relations [3]. Republicans are nearly twice as likely as Democrats (71% vs. 37%) to advocate holding China responsible at the expense of economic relations [3]. ![Public opinion on U.S. policy toward China](image4)

Long-term trends show a shift in attitudes toward China. From 2011 to 2020, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents have become increasingly critical, with their negative views rising from 51% to 66% [3]. Democrats and Democratic leaners, while also increasingly critical, have seen a smaller rise, from 32% to 33% [3]. ![Trends in Republican and Democratic views on China](image3)

Economic and trade policy preferences have fluctuated over the years. While 51% of Americans in 2020 supported building a stronger relationship with China, 46% favored getting tougher, reflecting a growing divide [6]. ![Trends in U.S. economic and trade policy toward China](image6)

Public perceptions of China have also shifted, with fewer viewing it as a competitor (57% in 2020, down from 66% in 2012) and more seeing it as an enemy (26% in 2020, up from 15% in 2012) [7]. ![Changing perceptions of China as a competitor, enemy, or partner](image7)

Overall, Americans’ views on China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations are deeply divided along partisan lines, with Republicans being more critical and supportive of tougher policies, while Democrats show more nuanced perspectives.

American perceptions of China's role in handling COVID-19 have significantly worsened, with a majority of respondents criticizing the Chinese government’s initial handling of the outbreak. According to a Pew Research Center survey, 64% of Americans view China’s handling of the coronavirus as "Bad," while only 31% see it as "Good" [image1]. Additionally, 78% of Americans place a "great deal" or "fair amount" of blame on the Chinese government for the global spread of the virus [image5]. This negative sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with 82% perceiving China’s handling as "Bad," compared to 54% of Democrats [image7].

![64% of Americans view China's handling of COVID-19 as "Bad" and 31% as "Good."](image1)  
![78% of Americans blame China significantly for the global spread of COVID-19.](image5)  

Broadly, American views of China have soured, with 73% of U.S. adults now holding an unfavorable view of the country, up from 47% in 2018 [text11]. This trend is evident across all age groups, with the sharpest increase among those aged 50 and older, where unfavorable views rose to 81% in 2020 [image6]. Republicans and Republican-leaners are more critical, with 83% holding unfavorable views, compared to 68% of Democrats [image4].

![73% of Americans hold an unfavorable view of China in 2020, up from 47% in 2018.](image8)  
![Unfavorable views of China have risen sharply, especially among those aged 50+.](image6)  

In terms of economic ties, 68% of Americans see U.S.-China economic relations as "bad," a 15-point increase since May 2019 [text12]. While 51% of Americans prefer pursuing a strong economic relationship with China, 50% believe the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic, even if it harms economic ties [text3, text6]. This divide is more pronounced among Republicans, with 71% prioritizing accountability over economic relations, compared to 37% of Democrats [text6].

![68% of Americans describe U.S.-China economic relations as "bad," a significant increase since 2019.](image4)  
![Republicans are twice as likely as Democrats to prioritize holding China accountable over economic ties.](image2)  

Overall, American perceptions of China have grown increasingly negative, with widespread blame for its handling of COVID-19 and a preference for accountability over economic cooperation, particularly among Republican-leaning individuals.

Negative perceptions of China have significantly increased over time across all age groups and political affiliations, with notable differences in the extent of these changes. ![Line graph showing a general upward trend in negative views across age groups from 2005 to 2020, with the 50+ group rising the most](image2)

Among age groups, Americans aged 50 and older have the most negative views of China, with 81% holding unfavorable opinions in 2020, a sharp increase from 34% in 2005. This contrasts with younger age groups, where 56% of those aged 18-29 and 71% of those aged 30-49 hold unfavorable views, though both groups have also seen significant increases since 2005 [5][7].

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents consistently hold more negative views than Democrats. In 2020, 83% of Republicans had unfavorable views of China compared to 68% of Democrats. This partisan gap has widened over time, with Republicans showing a 21-percentage-point increase since 2012, while Democrats increased by only 8 percentage points [1][2][3]. ![Line graph showing Republican and Democratic unfavorable views of China increasing over time, with Republicans consistently higher](image3)

Overall, negative views of China have reached historic highs, with 73% of Americans holding unfavorable opinions in 2020, up 26 percentage points since 2018 [8][10]. This trend is consistent across education levels and genders but is most pronounced among older Americans and Republicans. ![Bar chart displaying unfavorable views of China by age and political affiliation, showing higher percentages for older adults and Republicans](image7)

Unfavorable views of China have evolved significantly over time among different age groups and political affiliations in the United States. According to Pew Research Center data, negative sentiment has been on a steady rise since 2005, reaching historic highs in recent years.  

![Line graph showing trends in unfavorable views of China by age groups from 2005 to 2020](image5)  
The line graph reveals a consistent upward trend across all age groups. Among those aged 50 and older, unfavorable views increased from 34% in 2005 to 81% in 2020, marking the sharpest rise [5]. Similarly, the 30-49 age group saw an increase from 41% to 71%, while the 18-29 group rose from 26% to 56%. This shows that while older Americans are the most negative, all age groups have become increasingly unfavorable toward China.  

![Line graph showing trends in unfavorable views of China by political affiliation from 2005 to 2020](image2)  
Political affiliation also plays a significant role. Republicans and those leaning Republican have consistently held more negative views, rising from 39% in 2005 to 83% in 2020 [1]. Democrats and those leaning Democrat have also grown more unfavorable, though at a slower pace, increasing from 34% to 68% over the same period. The gap between the two political groups has widened, with Republicans now 15 percentage points more likely to hold very unfavorable views than Democrats [8].  

![Bar chart showing unfavorable views of China by age and political affiliation in 2020](image6)  
As of 2020, 73% of Americans overall have an unfavorable view of China, with Republicans (83%) and older adults (81%) leading this sentiment [10]. Democrats (68%) and younger adults (56%) are less negative but still reflect a significant shift toward unfavorable views compared to earlier years.  

In summary, unfavorable views of China have increased dramatically across all age groups and political affiliations, with older Americans and Republicans expressing the most negative sentiments. This trend has accelerated in recent years, reaching record highs in 2020.

Views on China vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, and these perceptions have shifted notably over time. 

Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and older, hold the most negative views of China, with **81%** expressing an unfavorable opinion compared to **56%** of those under 30 [6]. ![Trends in views of China by age groups show a significant rise in negative sentiment among older Americans over time](image2). This generational divide is further highlighted in perceptions of China’s relationship with the U.S., where only **6%** of those 50 and older see China as a partner, compared to **25%** of those aged 18-29 [11].

This gap has widened over time, with Republicans’ negative views increasing by **11 percentage points** in the past four months, compared to a **6-point** increase among Democrats [9]. 

The trend data reveals a consistent rise in unfavorable views across all groups since 2005, with a sharp increase in recent years. ![Unfavorable views of China have risen significantly across age groups and political affiliations since 2005](image7). Specifically, negative views have surged by **26 percentage points** since 2018, reaching **73%** of Americans today [7]. This suggests a broader, more entrenched shift in public opinion, particularly among older and Republican-leaning individuals. 

In summary, older Americans and Republicans hold the most negative views of China, and these perceptions have intensified over time. Younger Americans and Democrats, while still critical, are less overwhelmingly negative.

Negative opinions of China among different age groups and political affiliations in the United States have increased significantly over time. Let’s break this down by age and political affiliation.

### By Age
Older Americans have historically held more negative views of China compared to younger groups. In 2020, **81% of those aged 50 and older** had an unfavorable view of China, a significant increase of 10 percentage points since March 2020. For **ages 30 to 49**, 71% held unfavorable views, while **those under 30** had the lowest unfavorable rate at 56% [7]. Over the past 15 years, negative views have risen across all age groups, as illustrated by the line graph showing the increase from 2005 to 2020. For example, the "50 and older" group saw their unfavorable opinions rise from 34% in 2005 to 81% in 2020 [8].

![Unfavorable views of China have risen sharply among older Americans](image8)

### By Political Affiliation
Republicans consistently hold more negative views of China than Democrats. In 2020, **83% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** had an unfavorable view of China, compared to **68% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** [9]. This gap has widened over time, with Republican unfavorable views increasing by 11 percentage points in the four months leading up to July 2020, while Democrats saw a 6-point increase over the same period [8]. The line graph tracking partisan views from 2005 to 2020 shows that both groups have grown more critical, but Republicans have outpaced Democrats in their negativity [image2].

![Republicans hold significantly more unfavorable views of China than Democrats](image2)

### Overall Trends
Unfavorable views of China have reached historic highs, with **73% of Americans** holding negative opinions in July 2020, up 26 percentage points since 2018 [12]. This trend is evident across all demographics, but the intensity of negativity varies by age and political affiliation. 

In summary, negative opinions of China have consistently increased over time, with older Americans and Republicans expressing the most unfavorable views.

Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly shape preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. In the U.S., political affiliation dictates who people view as the most important foreign policy partner. While both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their top partner, Republicans are more inclined toward Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [2]. Democrats, on the other hand, prioritize Canada and Mexico more than Republicans [2]. However, both parties similarly rank Germany as their fifth most important partner [2]. ![Political affiliations in the U.S. influence foreign policy partner preferences](image8)

When it comes to cooperation, nearly seven-in-ten Americans (69%) want to cooperate more with Germany, while only half of Germans say the same about the U.S. [8]. This reflects a divergence in attitudes, though the percentage of Germans favoring increased cooperation with the U.S. has risen by nine points since 2018 [8]. Democrats in the U.S. are more likely than Republicans to desire greater cooperation with Germany, whereas in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. compared to supporters of the Greens and SPD [12]. ![Americans and Germans differ in their desire for cooperation with each other](image4)

In Germany, political differences are less dramatic, with supporters of the CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens all naming France as their top foreign policy partner, followed by the U.S. [7]. However, there is more support for a close relationship with Russia in the former East Germany (38%) compared to former West Germany (21%) [4]. ![East Germans prefer closer ties with Russia compared to West Germans](image1)

Overall, political affiliations in both countries influence not only the choice of foreign policy partners but also the level of desired international cooperation, with partisan divides shaping attitudes toward key nations like Russia, Germany, and the U.S.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China. Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia, with 66% of Germans favoring more cooperation compared to 35% of Americans [3]. This preference is particularly strong among Germans living in former East Germany, where 75% support increased cooperation with Russia, compared to 63% in former West Germany [3][10]. ![Germans are more likely to favor increased cooperation with Russia compared to Americans](image1)

In the U.S., political party affiliations influence views on cooperation with Russia. Republicans (41%) are more likely than Democrats (32%) to support increased collaboration with Russia [3]. Similarly, in Germany, ideological differences play a role, with conservatives and those on the right more likely to favor Russia compared to those on the left [5]. ![Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to favor cooperation with Russia than Democrats](image3)

Attitudes toward China also differ between the two countries. Germans are more likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% vs. 24%), while Americans are almost equally divided, with 41% favoring Germany and 44% favoring China [8]. Younger Americans (18-29) are more likely to prioritize a close relationship with China (58%) over Germany (32%), while older Americans show the opposite preference [7]. ![Germans prefer the U.S. over China more strongly than Americans](image8)

In Germany, political affiliations further shape these preferences. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [9]. ![CDU/CSU supporters in Germany are more likely to favor cooperation with the U.S. compared to Greens and SPD supporters](image2)

In summary, Germans are more supportive of increased cooperation with Russia compared to Americans, with strong regional and ideological divides in both countries. Americans are divided on cooperation with China, while Germans clearly prefer the U.S. over China, with political affiliations influencing these preferences in both nations.

Political party preferences in the U.S. and Germany significantly shape attitudes toward cooperation with other countries, particularly Russia and China. In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor closer ties with Russia (31% vs. 21%) [1]. This trend is reinforced by the fact that 41% of Republicans support greater cooperation with Russia compared to 32% of Democrats [11]. Similarly, ideological differences play a role, with conservative Americans more likely to view Russia favorably than liberals [8]. ![Republican and Democratic attitudes toward cooperation with Russia differ](image2)

In Germany, political affiliations also influence attitudes toward Russia. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, a center-right party, are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than with Russia, while those on the ideological right in Germany are more favorable toward the U.S. overall [6]. However, there is a notable regional divide, with East Germans being far more supportive of closer ties with Russia (38%) compared to West Germans (23%) [7]. ![East Germans show stronger support for cooperation with Russia](image7)

Regarding China, younger Americans (18–29 years old) are more likely to prioritize close relations with China over Germany (58% vs. 32%) [5], but this preference is less pronounced among older Americans. In Germany, 50% prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China, compared to 24% who favor China [9]. ![Germans prefer the U.S. over China for close relations](image2)

Overall, political affiliations in both countries significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia and China, with Republicans and conservatives in the U.S. and East Germans in Germany showing greater openness to collaboration with Russia, while younger Americans and Germans lean toward stronger ties with the U.S. over China. ![Political affiliations shape cooperation preferences in the U.S. and Germany](image5)

Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly shape attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with notable differences between parties and regions. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor closer ties with Russia compared to Democrats. Specifically, 31% of Republicans prefer close relations with Russia, while only 21% of Democrats share this view [3]. This partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that 41% of Republicans support increased cooperation with Russia, compared to 32% of Democrats [8].

![Political affiliations in the U.S. show Republicans favor Russia more than Democrats](image6)

In Germany, attitudes toward Russia are also influenced by political and regional factors. Germans living in former East Germany, where historical ties to Russia are stronger, are significantly more supportive of closer relations with Russia compared to those in the former West. For instance, 75% of East Germans favor greater cooperation with Russia, while only 63% of West Germans do [8]. Additionally, nearly four-in-ten East Germans prefer close ties with Russia, compared to just 23% who favor the U.S., whereas West Germans are twice as likely to prefer the U.S. over Russia [9].

![East Germans prioritize closer relations with Russia compared to West Germans](image4)

Overall, these differences reflect deeper ideological and historical divides. In the U.S., conservatives are generally more favorable toward Russia, while liberals tend to favor international organizations like the UN and EU [6]. In Germany, regional identities and historical context play a crucial role in shaping attitudes toward Russia, with East Germans showing stronger support for cooperation compared to their western counterparts. 

In summary, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with Republicans and East Germans showing greater support for closer ties.

When asked which country is the world’s leading economic power, Americans and Germans provide strikingly different answers. Half of Americans name the U.S., with about a third (32%) choosing China. In contrast, roughly half of Germans (53%) name China as the leading economic power, compared to only 24% who name the U.S. Relatively few in both countries see Japan or the European Union as the leading economic power, although 14% in Germany name the EU, about twice as many as in the U.S. [3] ![Americans see the U.S. as the leading economic power, while Germans favor China](image8).

When it comes to international relationships, Germans tend to view the EU more positively than Americans. About seven-in-ten Germans favor the EU, compared to only half of Americans [6]. ![Germans have a higher approval rating of the EU compared to Americans](image2). Similarly, Germans are more likely to view the U.S. as an important partner (42%) compared to how Americans view Germany (13%) ![Germans are more likely to see the U.S. as an important partner compared to Americans viewing Germany](image1).

Regarding China, Germans have a slightly more positive view (41% approval) compared to Americans (26%) [image2]. However, both countries show a significant divergence in their willingness to cooperate with one another. Nearly seven-in-ten Americans (69%) say they want to cooperate more with Germany, while only half of Germans say the same about the U.S. [11]. ![Germans and Americans differ in their willingness to cooperate with each other](image5).

In summary, Americans see the U.S. as the leading economic power, while Germans favor China. Germans also view the EU and the U.S. more positively than Americans, though both nations have mixed feelings about cooperation with each other.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their views of international organizations and economic powers, shaped by political, historical, and ideological factors. While both groups share relatively positive opinions of the UN and NATO, Germans tend to view these organizations more favorably than Americans (69% vs. 59% for the UN and 57% vs. 52% for NATO) [10]. Similarly, Germans show stronger support for the EU (69%) compared to Americans (51%) [5][10]. ![Germans have higher approval ratings for the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO compared to Americans](image5)

When it comes to perceptions of economic power, half of Americans believe the U.S. is the leading global economic power, while only 24% of Germans agree. Conversely, 53% of Germans see China as the top economic power, compared to 32% of Americans [7][8]. ![Americans see the U.S. as the top economic power, while Germans are more likely to name China](image1)

Political ideology significantly influences these views. In the U.S., conservatives are more likely than liberals to favor Russia, while liberals express stronger support for the UN and EU [11]. Germans also show ideological divides, with those on the political left more supportive of the UN and EU than those on the right [6]. ![Political ideology shapes perceptions of international entities in both the U.S. and Germany](image6)

Historical context also plays a role, particularly in Germany. Germans living in the former East Germany view Russia more favorably (43%) and the EU less favorably (59%) compared to those in the former West (33% and 71%, respectively) [4]. ![East Germans view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than West Germans](image2)

Additionally, Americans and Germans differ in their desire for bilateral cooperation. While 69% of Americans want to cooperate more with Germany, only 50% of Germans express the same sentiment toward the U.S., though this figure has increased since 2018 [5].

In summary, Americans and Germans diverge in their views of international organizations and economic powers due to differences in political ideology, historical experiences, and perceptions of global leadership.

Americans are significantly more likely than Germans to believe that military force is sometimes necessary. About eight-in-ten Americans agree with this view, compared to only half of Germans [9]. This divergence is also reflected in ideological divides within both countries—American conservatives are more likely (90%) than liberals (65%) to see military force as necessary, while in Germany, nearly six-in-ten on the right agree, compared to only a third on the left [1]. ![Americans are more likely than Germans to view military force as necessary](image4)

When it comes to defense spending, Americans and Germans show notable differences. Half of Americans believe their European allies should maintain current defense spending levels, a shift from 2017 when 45% favored increased spending [3]. In Germany, the public is divided, with about four-in-ten supporting either an increase or maintaining current spending levels [7]. ![Americans and Germans have differing opinions on defense spending](image6)

Young people in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-Germany relationship. In the U.S., 82% of those aged 18-29 view the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those 65 and older. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people view relations positively, while only 31% of those 65 and older share this sentiment [11]. ![Young people in both the U.S. and Germany have more positive views of bilateral relations](image3)

Americans and Germans hold significantly different views on military intervention and defense spending. Americans are more supportive of the use of military force, with about eight-in-ten believing it is sometimes necessary to maintain global order, compared to only half of Germans who agree [3]. This divide is further reflected in ideological differences: nine-in-ten American conservatives see military force as necessary, while only a third of German liberals share this view [1]. 

![A significant majority of Americans support military force compared to Germans.](image3)

When it comes to defense spending, Americans are more likely to favor increased spending by their European allies, though this support has declined in recent years. In 2019, 35% of Americans supported an increase in European defense spending, down from 45% in 2017 [12]. Germans, on the other hand, are split on whether to increase or maintain their own defense spending, with about four-in-ten supporting each option [9]. 

![American and German opinions on defense spending have shifted over time.](image5)

Additionally, Americans place greater importance on U.S. military bases in Germany, with 85% believing these bases are important to U.S. security, compared to only half of Germans who see them as important for their own security [5][8]. 

![Americans view U.S. military bases in Germany as more important than Germans do.](image2)

On NATO defense obligations, Americans and Germans also diverge. Six-in-ten Americans believe their country should defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, while an equal share of Germans oppose such intervention [10][11]. 

Overall, these differences highlight a broader gap in how Americans and Germans perceive security, military intervention, and defense spending.

Public opinion on defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany has shifted significantly over the years, with notable partisan differences within each country. In the U.S., opinions on whether European allies should increase defense spending have changed: in 2017, 45% of Americans supported an increase, but by 2019, this figure dropped to 35%. Conversely, those favoring maintaining the same spending levels rose from 37% in 2017 to 50% in 2019 [1][3]. ![Comparative bar chart showing Americans' and Germans' opinions on defense spending](image1)

Partisan divides in the U.S. are evident, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to support increased defense spending in Europe. However, support among Republicans has declined by 14 percentage points from 2017 to 2019, while Democrats have shown a more modest decrease [9]. ![Line graph showing declining support for increased defense spending among Republicans and Democrats](image2)

In Germany, public opinion is more divided. In 2017, 32% supported increasing defense spending, rising to 40% by 2019, while those favoring maintaining current levels dropped from 51% to 41% [1][8]. Partisan gaps in Germany are also prominent, with CDU/CSU supporters more likely to favor increased spending (51%), compared to Greens (28%) and SPD supporters (41%) [11]. ![Horizontal bar chart comparing defense spending opinions across German political parties](image6)

Both countries show a trend of shifting opinions, with Americans becoming less supportive of increased European defense spending and Germans remaining divided on the issue. Partisan differences persist, with Republicans in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany more inclined to advocate for higher defense budgets.

From 2017 to 2019, American and German views on national defense spending shifted noticeably. In the U.S., support for European allies increasing their defense spending declined. In 2017, 45% of Americans favored increased spending by European allies, but by 2019, this figure dropped to 35%. Meanwhile, 50% of Americans in 2019 preferred maintaining current spending levels, up from 37% in 2017 [7]. ![Americans shifted toward maintaining defense spending levels for European allies](image4). In Germany, the public remained divided, with 40% supporting increased defense spending in 2019, compared to 32% in 2017, while 41% favored maintaining current levels [4].

Partisan differences are evident in both countries. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents were more likely than Democrats to support increased defense spending in Europe, though this support among Republicans fell by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [12]. ![Decline in Republican support for increased defense spending among European allies](image3). In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU were more in favor of defense spending increases (51%), while only 28% of Greens supported such increases, with SPD supporters falling in the middle at 41% [1]. ![Partisan differences in Germany regarding defense spending increases](image8).

Germans also showed generational divides, with younger Germans (18-29) being more skeptical of the importance of U.S. military bases, while 61% of those 65 and older viewed them as important to national security [10]. ![Younger Germans are less supportive of U.S. military bases in Germany](image5). Overall, both countries experienced evolving views on defense spending, with significant partisan and generational differences shaping public opinion.

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly shape opinions on increasing defense spending, and these views have evolved over time. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [2]. However, support among Republicans for European allies increasing their defense budgets has declined by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, with a more modest decline among Democrats [2]. ![A line graph showing the decline in support for increased defense spending among Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019.](image7)

In Germany, partisan differences are also evident. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more in favor of defense spending increases, with 51% supporting it, while only 28% of Greens and 41% of SPD supporters agree [4][9]. ![A horizontal bar chart showing the percentage of CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens supporters in Germany who favor increased defense spending.](image4)

Public opinion on defense spending has fluctuated over the years. In the U.S., support for increasing defense spending among European allies peaked at 45% in 2017 but dropped to 35% by 2019, while the preference for maintaining current spending levels increased [8]. In Germany, support for increasing defense spending rose from 32% in 2017 to 40% in 2019, with a majority favoring either maintaining or reducing spending [8]. ![A comparative bar chart showing U.S. and German opinions on national defense spending from 2017 to 2019.](image8)

Overall, political affiliations in both countries strongly influence views on defense spending, with Republicans and CDU/CSU supporters being the most supportive, though this support has declined or shifted over time.

Age differences in Germany significantly influence perceptions of the importance of U.S. military bases in the country. Younger Germans, particularly those aged 18 to 29, are more skeptical, with roughly six-in-ten believing that U.S. military bases do not contribute to German national security. In contrast, 61% of Germans aged 65 and older view these bases as important to Germany’s defense [10]. This generational divide is also reflected in broader attitudes, as older Germans are more likely to see the U.S. as a vital foreign policy partner compared to their younger counterparts [1]. ![Older Germans view U.S. military bases as more important than younger Germans](image8)

In the U.S., political affiliations shape perceptions of foreign policy partners and the importance of military bases in Germany. Both Republicans and Democrats rank the U.K. as their most important partner, but Republicans are more favorable toward Israel, while Democrats place greater emphasis on Canada and Mexico [9]. ![Republicans and Democrats differ in their preferences for foreign policy partners](image1) Despite these differences, support for the U.S. military presence in Germany is strong among both parties, with 85% of Americans overall believing these bases are important to U.S. security [8]. ![U.S. respondents view the military presence in Germany as very important compared to Germans](image3) 

These trends highlight how age and political affiliation create distinct perspectives on foreign policy and military cooperation across the two countries.

Views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues vary significantly across political affiliations and educational backgrounds. 

### Political Affiliations:
- **Republicans**: Around 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems rather than help other countries [7]. This view is consistent across both conservative and moderate Republicans, with 76% and 74% respectively holding this stance [image5]. Republicans also tend to praise the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak, with 71% approving [11]. However, conservative Republicans are particularly critical of China’s handling of the pandemic, with 80% viewing it negatively [4].

- **Democrats**: Democrats are more divided, with 53% overall supporting the U.S. helping other countries deal with their problems [3]. This is especially true for liberal Democrats, where 64% advocate for international assistance, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [3]. Democrats are also more critical of the U.S.’s handling of the pandemic, with 73% expressing dissatisfaction [11]. Liberal Democrats are particularly negative, with 81% rating the U.S. response as only fair or poor [12].

### Educational Backgrounds:
- **Higher Education**: Individuals with postgraduate degrees are more supportive of international engagement, with 60% believing the U.S. should help other countries [6]. Similarly, postgraduates are more critical of the U.S. pandemic response, with 66% rating it as poor [10].

- **Lower Education**: Those with a high school diploma or less are more likely to prioritize domestic issues, with 69% saying the U.S. should focus on its own problems [6]. They are also less critical of the U.S. response to the pandemic, with 43% rating it as poor [10]. 

![Republicans and Democrats differ sharply on engagement and pandemic response](image5)  
![Postgraduates are more supportive of international engagement than those with less education](image6)

In summary, Republicans and individuals with lower education levels prefer the U.S. to focus on domestic issues, while Democrats and highly educated individuals are more supportive of international engagement and critical of the U.S. pandemic response.

Political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly shape Americans' perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Partisan divides are particularly stark: 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise the U.S. response, compared to just 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [6]. This gap is narrower when evaluating other countries, such as Italy, South Korea, and Germany, where differences in opinion between Democrats and Republicans are less than 10 percentage points [3]. ![Partisan gap in U.S. response](image6)

Education also plays a role, particularly in how Americans view the U.S. response. Around two-thirds of those with postgraduate degrees and six-in-ten college graduates say the U.S. has done a poor job, while only four-in-ten with a high school degree or less share this view [10]. ![Education-level perceptions](image2)

Regarding China, partisan differences are also evident. While majorities across all educational groups criticize China's handling of the pandemic, Republicans, especially conservative ones, are more likely to hold this view (80%) compared to Democrats [9]. Older Americans, who tend to have less favorable attitudes toward China, are also more critical, with 69% of those aged 65 and older saying China has done a fair or poor job [11]. ![Demographic views on China](image6)

In summary, political affiliations create a strong divide in perceptions of the U.S. response, with Republicans more supportive and Democrats more critical. Educational background further influences these views, with more educated Americans being more critical of the U.S. response. Partisanship also drives differing opinions on China’s handling of the pandemic, with Republicans and older Americans being the most negative.

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Regarding the U.S., there is a stark partisan divide: 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, compared to just 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [3]. This polarization extends to evaluations of the World Health Organization (WHO), with 62% of Democrats praising its handling of the pandemic, while only 28% of Republicans share this view [7].

When it comes to China, both parties largely agree that its response has been poor, but Republicans are more critical. Eight-in-ten conservative Republicans believe China has not handled the crisis well, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats [9]. ![Political leanings significantly influence evaluations of China’s COVID-19 response](image7).

The partisan divide is less pronounced in assessments of other countries like Italy, South Korea, and Germany, where differences between Democrats and Republicans are minimal [11]. Overall, political affiliation remains a key determinant in shaping perceptions of pandemic responses, particularly for the U.S. and China. ![Republicans and Democrats differ in their evaluations of pandemic handling](image8).

Perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus vary significantly across political affiliations. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with 67% of liberal Democrats holding this view, compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans [8]. Similarly, 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say the U.S. can learn a great deal, while just 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this perspective [5]. This partisan divide is also reflected in evaluations of the U.S.'s current handling of the pandemic; those who think the U.S. can learn from abroad are less positive about its performance, with only 44% saying the country is doing an excellent or good job, compared to 63% of those who believe the U.S. can’t learn much from overseas [1].

Trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU also follows a partisan pattern. Liberal Democrats are far more likely to trust information from these sources, with 86% saying they trust the WHO at least a fair amount, compared to just 27% of conservative Republicans [2]. Similarly, 79% of liberal Democrats trust information from the EU, while only 49% of conservative Republicans do [3]. This divide is consistently larger than differences based on education or age, which are relatively minor in comparison [10].

![A chart showing trust levels in WHO, EU, and Chinese government across political groups, with Liberal Democrats most trusting and Conservative Republicans least trusting.](image3)

Education also plays a role in trust levels, with those holding postgraduate degrees showing higher confidence in international organizations. For example, 78% of postgraduate degree holders trust information from the EU, and 70% trust the WHO, compared to those with less education [6][7]. Younger Americans also tend to trust these organizations more than older Americans, with 52% of adults under 30 saying the WHO has done an excellent or good job, compared to just 39% of those 65 and older [11].

![A chart showing trust levels by education and age, with higher education and younger age groups showing greater trust in international organizations.](image2)

In summary, perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU are deeply influenced by political affiliation, with Democrats and individuals with higher education levels showing greater openness to learning from abroad and trusting international sources.

Views about the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen, while Democrats are four times more likely than Republicans to expect a decline. Among Democrats, liberal supporters are 20 percentage points more likely than conservatives and moderates to foresee a weakening of U.S. influence [1]. Similarly, 45% of Americans with higher education levels think the country’s global influence will recede, compared to those with less education [10].  

![Public perceptions of U.S., EU, and China's future influence vary by education and political affiliation.](image1)  

For China, roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe its international clout will diminish due to the pandemic, compared to just 40% of Democrats [6]. Older Americans, particularly those 65 and older, are 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to think China’s global influence will decrease [6].  

![Half of Americans believe China's influence will decline post-pandemic, with partisan and age-based divides.](image4)  

Regarding the EU, majorities in both parties think its international influence will remain unaffected by the pandemic [3]. However, there are slight variations across political affiliations, with 24% of Democrats/Lean Democrats and 13% of Republicans/Lean Republicans believing the EU’s influence will grow [8].  

![Perceptions of the EU's future influence show less partisan divide compared to the U.S. and China.](image8)  

In summary, political affiliation and education level significantly shape views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China, with Republicans and older, less-educated Americans more likely to foresee declines in China’s influence, while Democrats and higher-educated individuals are more pessimistic about the U.S.’s global role.

Predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly across demographic and political groups in the United States.

Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to have negative views of China, with 65+ year-olds being 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to say China will have less global influence post-pandemic [11]. Partisan divides are evident, as roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international clout will diminish, compared to just 40% of Democrats [12]. ![Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to predict diminished Chinese influence](image1)

Regarding U.S. influence, Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen, while Democrats are four times more likely to expect it to weaken [3]. Education also plays a role, with those holding higher degrees more likely to predict a decline in U.S. influence [9]. ![Republicans are more optimistic about U.S. influence post-pandemic](image6)

Half of Americans believe China will have less influence after the outbreak, while only a third think the same about the U.S. [10]. This is reflected in the chart showing 50% predict less influence for China, compared to 29% for the U.S. ![Half of Americans predict less influence for China post-pandemic](image7)

In summary, Republicans and older Americans are more pessimistic about China’s future influence, while Republicans are more optimistic about the U.S.’s global standing. Democrats and those with higher education levels tend to predict a decline in U.S. influence.

Americans’ perceptions of China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak and its future influence in world affairs are largely negative and heavily influenced by partisan divides. Nearly two-thirds of Americans say China has not done a good job dealing with the outbreak, with 37% stating it has done a poor job [9]. This sentiment is more pronounced among Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, 80% of whom believe China has not handled the crisis well [2]. Democrats, while still critical, are less likely to hold this view, with only half expressing similar disapproval [10].

Regarding China’s future global influence, half of Americans believe China’s international clout will decline after the pandemic, while 31% think it will remain the same, and 17% believe it will grow [11]. ![Half of Americans believe China's global influence will decline](image7) Partisan differences are stark here as well: 60% of Republicans anticipate a decline in China’s influence, compared to only 40% of Democrats [5]. Older Americans (65+) are also more likely than younger adults to believe China’s influence will diminish [5].

These partisan divides are consistent with broader trends in attitudes toward China. Negative views of China have risen significantly among both Democrats and Republicans, but Republicans express significantly more unfavorable opinions [10]. This polarization is reflected in evaluations of international organizations like the WHO, where Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to trust the organization’s handling of the pandemic [4][8].

In summary, Americans broadly criticize China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak and expect its global influence to decline, with Republicans holding more negative views than Democrats.

Partisan views on the U.S. role in solving world problems and its influence post-COVID-19 show clear and growing divisions from 2013 to 2020. Republicans and Democrats have sharply differing opinions on both issues.

![The orange line shows an increasing trend in Republicans believing the U.S. does "too much" in solving world problems, rising from 52% in 2013 to 62% in 2020.](image3) Republicans have increasingly believed that the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges, rising from $52\%$ in 2013 to $62\%$ in 2020 [7]. Partisan views on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic are markedly divided. A majority of liberal Democrats **(67%)** believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations about slowing the spread of COVID-19, compared to just **25%** of conservative Republicans [5]. ![Liberal Democrats are significantly more likely to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries about COVID-19](image5)

This divide is also evident in opinions about the U.S.'s global role. While **64%** of liberal Democrats think the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, only **22%** of conservative Republicans share this view [9]. ![Liberal Democrats are more supportive of the U.S. helping other countries than conservative Republicans](image5)

Partisan differences extend to assessments of U.S. influence post-pandemic. **56%** of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the outbreak, compared to just **8%** of conservative Republicans [3]. ![Liberal Democrats are more pessimistic about U.S. global influence post-pandemic](image5)

These divisions are reflected in broader trends over time. The partisan gap in views on the U.S.'s role in solving world problems has widened significantly since 2013, with Republicans increasingly supporting a focus on domestic issues and Democrats leaning toward international engagement. ![Partisan divisions on the U.S.'s role in solving world problems have grown since 2013](image1)

Overall, liberal Democrats are more likely to advocate for learning from other countries and supporting global cooperation, while conservative Republicans favor a more insular approach.

Views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries vary significantly across political affiliations and educational levels. Overall, $60\%$ of Americans believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while $39\%$ think it should assist other nations [4]. 

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to prioritize domestic issues, with $76\%$ advocating for the U.S. to deal with its own problems. This view is consistent across conservative and moderate/liberal Republicans, with $76\%$ and $74\%$ respectively supporting this stance [image6]. In contrast, Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more divided: $53\%$ believe the U.S. should help other countries, while $46\%$ favor focusing on domestic issues. This divide is more pronounced among liberal Democrats, with $64\%$ supporting international assistance, compared to $44\%$ of conservative and moderate Democrats [6][image6].

Educational attainment also influences these views. Among postgraduates, $60\%$ support the U.S. helping other countries, while $39\%$ prefer focusing on domestic issues. College graduates are evenly split at $49\%$ for both positions. ![Views on U.S. role by political affiliation and education are sharply divided.](image6) 

In summary, Republicans and those with lower educational levels are more likely to advocate for the U.S. to focus on its own problems, while Democrats and individuals with higher education are more supportive of international assistance.

Perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems vary significantly by political affiliation and have undergone notable changes over time. Currently, a majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, while only 8% think it does too little and 29% say it does the right amount [2]. Conversely, a plurality of Democrats (48%) say the U.S. does too little, with 26% each believing it does the right amount or too much [2]. This partisan divide is more pronounced today compared to previous years, where differences were less stark [5]. ![Majority of Republicans now say U.S. does too much to solve world problems](image1)

Over time, the gap between Republican and Democratic views has widened. In 2013, 51% of Republicans thought the U.S. did too much, a figure that has risen to 62% by 2020. Among Democrats, the share believing the U.S. does too little increased from 17% in 2013 to 28% in 2018, then stabilized [8]. ![Changes in opinions from 2013 to 2020](image6)

Regarding the U.S. role in helping other countries, Republicans overwhelmingly favor the U.S. focusing on its own problems (76%), while Democrats are more divided, with 53% supporting assistance to other countries and 46% advocating for prioritizing domestic issues [1]. ![U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries handle theirs](image2)

In summary, Republicans increasingly perceive the U.S. as overextending itself globally, while Democrats lean toward a more active international role, and these views have become more polarized over the past decade.

Views on U.S. global engagement and domestic focus vary significantly by political affiliation and educational attainment. Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. does too much to solve global problems, with 62% holding this view, compared to just 26% of Democrats [1]. Conversely, a plurality of Democrats (48%) say the U.S. does too little to help with global issues, while only 8% of Republicans share this perspective [1]. This partisan divide is further highlighted in image8, where the orange line ("Too much") rises sharply to 62% for Republicans in 2020, while only 26% of Democrats hold this view [image8].

Educational attainment also influences these opinions. Postgraduates are more supportive of global engagement, with 60% saying the U.S. should help other countries, compared to 39% overall [3]. ![Postgraduates are more supportive of global engagement](image7) Among Republicans with some college or less education, 76% believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems, while only 23% of postgraduate Republicans agree [7]. Similarly, Democrats with postgraduate degrees are more likely to support global engagement, with 64% of liberal Democrats favoring helping other countries [2].

When it comes to domestic versus global focus, 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents prefer the U.S. to address its own problems, compared to 46% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [9]. ![Republicans are more focused on domestic issues](image7) This trend is consistent across education levels, with 60% of postgraduates favoring global engagement, while 69% of those with a high school diploma or less prioritize domestic issues [7].

In summary, Republicans and those with lower educational attainment tend to favor a domestic focus, while Democrats, especially those with higher education, are more supportive of global engagement.

Americans have significant concerns about issues related to China, with cyberattacks and China’s growing military power being among the most serious. Around 65% of Americans view cyberattacks from China as a very serious problem, while 52% say the same about China’s military power [12]. These concerns are reflected in their confidence levels in President Biden’s ability to handle China, which is notably lower compared to their expectations for other foreign policy issues. For example, only 53% of Americans express confidence in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China, the lowest among six tested foreign policy areas, where confidence ranges from 59% to 67% [5]. 

![Concerns about cyberattacks and military power are high among Americans](image7)  
![Americans have less confidence in Biden on China compared to other foreign policy issues](image6)

Partisan differences also play a significant role. Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more likely than Democrats to view issues like cyberattacks and military power as very serious, with 73% of Republicans seeing cyberattacks as a very serious problem compared to 60% of Democrats [2]. Similarly, only 19% of Republicans have confidence in Biden’s ability to handle China, compared to 83% of Democrats [7]. This stark divide suggests that while concerns about China are widespread, confidence in Biden’s ability to address these issues is heavily influenced by political affiliation.

![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view China as a threat](image8)  
![Women and ethnic minorities express higher confidence in Biden on China compared to White men](image4)

Overall, while Americans rank issues like cyberattacks and China’s military power as highly serious, their confidence in Biden’s ability to deal with China is comparatively lower, especially among Republicans.

Confidence in President Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic groups. **Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%)**, and **Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%)** [10]. Additionally, those with a college degree (60%) are more confident than those without one (50%) [10]. Politically, **83% of Democrats and Democratic leaners have confidence in Biden, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners** [7]. Among Republicans, conservatives (10%) are far less confident than moderates or liberals (30%) [7].

![Demographic confidence in Biden to deal with China](image7)

Americans’ primary concerns regarding China include **cyberattacks (65% very serious), China’s growing military power (52% very serious), the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53% very serious), and China’s human rights policies (50% very serious)** [12]. These issues, along with the U.S. trade deficit with China (43% very serious) and China’s technological power (47% very serious), dominate public concern [8]. Tensions between mainland China and Hong Kong (31% very serious) or Taiwan (28% very serious) are seen as less pressing [3].

![Primary concerns regarding China](image8)

In summary, confidence in Biden on China is highest among Democrats, women, and minorities, while Republicans and less-educated individuals are more skeptical. The primary concerns about China focus on cybersecurity, military expansion, job loss, and human rights.

Confidence in President Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic and political groups. Education level also plays a role, with 60% of college graduates showing confidence compared to 50% of those with less education [11].

The partisan divide is stark: 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents have confidence in Biden, while only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners do [3]. Conservative Republicans are even less confident (10%) compared to moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [12]. ![Demographic confidence levels in Biden on China](image3)

These concerns have grown over the past year, particularly among Republicans. For example, the share of Republicans who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem increased from 52% in 2020 to 66% in 2021 [7]. ![Partisan differences in concerns about China](image7)

In summary, confidence in Biden’s ability to handle China is higher among Democrats, women, and minority groups, but significantly lower among Republicans. The most serious concerns about China center on cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies.

Tensions between mainland China and Hong Kong or Taiwan are seen as less critical, with only about 30% viewing them as very serious [1].

![Major concerns about China's impact on the U.S.](image3)
