The shift from desktop to mobile internet usage also played a crucial role, with mobile usage rising from 32% in 2011 to 61% in 2014, making eCommerce more accessible[4]. ![Mobile internet usage increased from 32% in 2011 to 61% in 2014.](image4)

In summary, the growth in digital platforms and social media drove a rapid increase in digital advertising spend, expanded eCommerce revenues, and transformed payment preferences, making digital the cornerstone of India’s advertising and eCommerce ecosystem during this period.

The organizational structure of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is hierarchically managed under the Department of Space (DOS). At the top is the Prime Minister of India, followed by the Space Commission, which formulates policies and oversees the implementation of the Indian space programme. The DOS implements these policies through various entities, primarily ISRO, along with Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC), and Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL). The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) further encompasses several specialized centers and units that focus on different aspects of space research and technology.

![Organizational Chart of the Department of Space](image2)

ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC) in Bengaluru is one of the key centers, responsible for the design, development, fabrication, and testing of all Indian-made satellites. Other important facilities include the Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) in Thiruvananthapuram, the Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SHAR) in Sriharikota, and the Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre (LPSC). Additionally, ISRO Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network (ISTRAC) in Bengaluru provides tracking support for satellite and launch vehicle missions. The organizational chart illustrates the comprehensive structure and interconnectedness of these centers and units under the umbrella of ISRO and DOS.

![Map of ISRO Facilities Across India](image3)

The budget allocation for ISRO’s programs for the financial years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 is illustrated in the provided bar chart. The categories include Space Technology, Space Applications, INSAT Operational, Space Sciences, and Direction & Administration and Other Programmes. For 2015-2016, the Budget Estimates (BE) and Revised Estimates (RE) show allocations of 4596.2 and 4351.78 crore INR respectively for Space Technology, 962.32 and 967.63 crore INR for Space Applications, 1320.95 and 1167.75 crore INR for INSAT Operational, 300.25 and 297.75 crore INR for Space Sciences, and 208.47 and 174.53 crore INR for Direction & Administration and Other Programmes. For 2016-2017, the Budget Estimates (BE) are 5235.68 crore INR for Space Technology, 1034.39 crore INR for Space Applications, 796.1 crore INR for INSAT Operational, 288.95 crore INR for Space Sciences, and 154.02 crore INR for Direction & Administration and Other Programmes.

![Budget Allocation of ISRO Programs](image1)

In summary, ISRO’s organizational structure is a well-defined hierarchy under the Department of Space, encompassing various specialized centers and units. The budget allocation for its programs in 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 reflects significant investment in Space Technology, followed by Space Applications and INSAT Operational, with smaller portions allocated to Space Sciences and administrative functions.

The Indian Space Programme is a multifaceted initiative managed by the Department of Space (DOS) and implemented through various centers and organizations. Each center has a distinct role, contributing to different aspects of space science, technology, and applications.  

![Map of India showing key space research locations](image1)  
The map highlights the geographic distribution of ISRO and DOS facilities across India, underscoring their widespread presence and regional significance. For instance, Bengaluru serves as the hub with ISRO Headquarters, ISRO Satellite Centre, and Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre, while Chandigarh hosts the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL), focusing on VLSI and microelectronics development [1][8]. Thiruvananthapuram is home to the Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre and Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre, pivotal for launch vehicle and propulsion technologies.  

![Budget allocation chart for space programs](image2)  
The budget allocations reflect the strategic priorities of the Indian Space Programme. For example, the highest allocation in 2016-2017 was for Space Technology (₹5235.68 crore), indicating the emphasis on developing advanced technologies for satellites and launch vehicles. Space Applications received ₹1034.39 crore, highlighting its role in utilizing space technology for socio-economic benefits, while Space Sciences, though allocated a smaller budget (₹288.95 crore), remains critical for fundamental research in atmospheric and planetary sciences [1].  

![Organizational chart of the Department of Space](image3)  
The organizational structure shows the hierarchical relationship between the Space Commission, DOS, ISRO, and specialized centers like the Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), and North-Eastern Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC). These centers focus on specific domains such as atmospheric research, regional development, and space science education [1][9].  

![Infrared Observatory at Mt. Abu](image7)  
Centers like the Infrared Observatory at Mt. Abu contribute to advanced astronomical research, while the MST Radar facility at NARL, shown below, is instrumental in atmospheric studies and weather prediction [8].  
![MST Radar facility at NARL](image8)  

The Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) in Chandigarh plays a crucial role in indigenizing electronics and semiconductor technologies, as seen in the cleanroom environment where complex fabrication processes are carried out [5].  
![Cleanroom environment in a semiconductor lab](image5)  

Institutions like the Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) and the Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS) focus on education and training, ensuring a skilled workforce for the space sector.  
![IIRS Main Building](image4)  
![ITC Building](image6)  

In summary, the roles of different centers under the Indian Space Programme are diverse, ranging from technology development and atmospheric research to education and regional applications. Their budget allocations reflect their strategic importance, with Space Technology receiving the highest funding, followed by Space Applications and Space Sciences. Together, these centers ensure India’s continued progress in space exploration and its socio-economic utilization.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) and the Semiconductor Laboratory (SCL) serve distinct yet vital roles in India’s space and technology sectors.

NARL, located in Gadanki near Tirupati, is dedicated to atmospheric research with a vision to predict the behavior of the Earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling [3]. Its functions include technology development, data collection, archival, and assimilation, as well as atmospheric modeling [3]. The MST Radar facility at NARL, depicted in the image, features a complex array of antennas used for atmospheric and meteorological studies, supporting its mission to analyze weather and climate patterns. ![The MST Radar facility at NARL is used for atmospheric research](image2)

On the other hand, SCL in Chandigarh focuses on creating a strong microelectronics base in India, with expertise in the design, development, and fabrication of CMOS and MEMS devices [7]. The image of the cleanroom environment at SCL highlights its advanced semiconductor fabrication capabilities, where workers in protective suits handle complex machinery to produce high-reliability electronic components. ![SCL’s cleanroom environment supports semiconductor fabrication](image3) SCL has also successfully processed production lots, including the Vikram Processor for Launch Vehicles, showcasing its role in critical technological advancements [4].

Both facilities are integral to India’s space and technology programs, with NARL focusing on atmospheric research and SCL driving semiconductor innovation.

Technology usage within households and outside households varies significantly, with mobile phones being the most commonly owned device both at home and outside, while access to computers and the internet is more limited. Within households, **86% own mobile phones**, **49% own televisions**, and **45% own radios**, with computers and internet access at **10% and 5%** respectively [image3]. Outside the household, **68% do not use any technology**, while **20% use mobile phones**, **11% use televisions**, and **4% use computers or the internet** [image7]. 

Radio listening habits are influenced by these differences in technology access. **76% of respondents listen to the radio via a radio set**, while **40% use mobile phones** [image4]. Rural areas show a higher reliance on traditional radio sets (**77%**), while urban areas slightly favor mobile phones (**49%**) for radio listening [image4]. Gender also plays a role, with **75% of males** and **77% of females** using radio sets, though males are more likely to use mobile phones for listening (**43% vs. 36%**) [image4]. 

Radio program preferences further highlight demographic trends. News is the most listened-to content (**82%**), followed by music (**58%**) [image6]. This aligns with the infographic showing **62% of radio content devoted to news** and **27% to music** [image2]. However, **46% of respondents never listen to the radio**, with rural and urban areas showing similar patterns in listening frequency [image5]. 

In summary, mobile phones dominate technology usage both inside and outside households, but traditional radio sets remain the primary medium for radio listening, especially in rural areas. Radio content preferences and listening habits are shaped by demographics, with news and music being the most popular. ![Technology access in households](image3) ![Radio listening devices](image4) ![Radio program preferences](image6)

Television is accessed more frequently on a daily basis compared to newspapers. According to the data, 32% of people watch television every day, while only 9% read newspapers daily [image7] [image4]. On the other hand, newspapers are more often never accessed, with 70% of respondents reporting they never read newspapers, compared to 23% who never watch television [image4] [image7].

![32% of people watch TV every day.](image7)  
![9% of people read newspapers every day.](image4)  
![70% of respondents never read newspapers.](image4)  
![23% of respondents never watch TV.](image7)

The frequency of accessing newspapers and television varies significantly among the survey population. According to the data, 9% of respondents read newspapers every day, while 32% watch television every day [1]. 

![9% of respondents read newspapers every day](image1)  
![32% of respondents watch television every day](image4)

For occasional usage, 11% read newspapers a few times a week compared to 15% for television. Similarly, 10% read newspapers a few times a month, while only 8% watch television at the same frequency [1]. 

Finally, a substantial 70% of respondents never read newspapers, whereas only 23% never watch television [1]. This suggests that television is a more frequently accessed medium compared to newspapers in this survey population. 

In summary, television is accessed more frequently than newspapers, with a significant majority never engaging with newspapers but regularly watching TV.

To compare the frequency of media access across radio, newspapers, television, and internet, we can analyze the provided infographics and data. 

![Frequency of media consumption among different types](image1)  
Radio is the most frequently accessed medium, with 46% of people consuming it daily [image1]. Television follows with 32% daily usage [image6], while newspapers and internet have significantly lower daily usage at 9% [image5] and 7% [image3], respectively. 

In terms of non-users, newspapers have the highest percentage, with 70% of respondents never reading them [image5]. The internet also has a high percentage of non-users, with 82% never using a laptop [image3]. Television and radio have lower percentages of non-users, at 23% [image6] and 23% [image4], respectively.

In summary, **radio has the highest daily usage**, while **newspapers have the highest percentage of non-users**.

To compare the frequency of access to television, newspapers, and the internet among people, let’s analyze the data from the provided images.

- **Television**: According to the infographic in **image2**, 32% of people watch TV every day, 15% watch it a few times a week, 8% watch it a few times a month, and 23% never watch TV.  
  ![32% of people watch TV every day](image2)

- **Newspapers**: As shown in **image8**, 9% of people read newspapers every day, 11% read them a few times a week, 10% read them a few times a month, and 70% never read newspapers.  
  ![70% of people never read newspapers](image8)

- **Internet**: Based on **image6**, 7% of people use laptops (an indicator of internet access) every day, 7% use them a few times a week, 4% use them a few times a month, and 82% never use laptops.  
  ![82% of people never use laptops](image6)

Among the three media types, **the internet (through laptops)** has the highest percentage of people who never access it, at 82%. Newspapers follow with 70%, and television has the lowest percentage of non-users at 23%.

To compare the frequency of access to television and internet, we can analyze the data from the provided text and image quotes. 

From **image5**, the infographic shows that **32% of people watch television every day**, with 15% watching a few times a week, 8% a few times a month, and 23% never watching TV.

In contrast, **image6** depicts laptop usage, which can be used as a proxy for internet access. It shows that only **7% of respondents use their laptops every day**, with another 7% using them a few times a week, 4% a few times a month, and a significant 82% never using laptops.

![32% of people watch television every day](image5)  
![Only 7% of respondents use laptops every day](image6)  

Based on this data, **television is used more frequently on a daily basis compared to the internet**.

Among the surveyed population, television is accessed more frequently than the internet. According to the data, 32% of respondents watch TV every day, while only 7% use the internet daily [3]. Additionally, 15% watch TV a few times a week compared to 7% for the internet [3]. This suggests a stronger preference for television as a medium of consumption among the surveyed group.

![32% of respondents watch TV every day, while only 7% use the internet daily.](image8)  
![7% of respondents use their laptops daily.](image3)  

The infographic also reveals that 23% of respondents never watch TV, while 82% never use laptops, indicating that television remains a more widely adopted medium compared to internet-based consumption [3].

These patterns highlight a significant divide in media consumption habits, with traditional media like television still dominating over digital platforms. This could be attributed to factors such as accessibility, familiarity, and infrastructure limitations, particularly in rural areas, where 83% of the surveyed population resides [4].

![83% of the surveyed population resides in rural areas.](image6)  

Inference from these behaviors suggests that while digital media is growing, traditional media remains a cornerstone of information dissemination in Nepal, especially in regions with limited internet penetration. This underscores the importance of continued investment in digital infrastructure to bridge the gap in media access.

The population distribution by caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location in Nepal as of September 2014 reveals distinct demographic patterns. 

![The table displays data on the distribution of different castes and ethnicities within a population.](image4) The caste/ethnicity distribution shows significant representation of groups like Chhetri (15.3%), Brahman-Hill (12.2%), and Magar (7.1%). These groups collectively dominate the population, with Non-Madhesi groups accounting for 64.7% and Madhesi groups for 35.3% [5]. 

![The table displays the percentage of the population adhering to different religions over two time points.](image8) Religiously, Hinduism remains predominant at 84.9%, followed by Buddhism (8.2%) and Islam (4.3%). Other religions like Christianity, Kirat, and Atheist have smaller but notable shares.

![The table displays the distribution of population percentages across three regions: Mountain, Hill, and Tarai.](image10) Geographically, the Tarai region holds the majority at 50.2%, followed by the Hill region at 43.1%, and the Mountain region at 6.7%. This aligns with the ecological and development region distribution, which reflects the national population [4]. 

In summary, the population in September 2014 was predominantly Non-Madhesi by caste/ethnicity, Hindu by religion, and concentrated in the Tarai region geographically.

The demographic composition of the population, particularly in terms of rural-urban distribution and caste/ethnicity, shows notable stability over time. According to the data, 83% of respondents lived in rural areas, while 17% were from urban areas, reflecting the national distribution as per the 2011 census. This consistency is evident in both the initial period and September 2014, as shown in the table: ![83% rural and 17% urban population distribution remains unchanged](image8).

Regarding caste and ethnicity, the data indicates slight shifts in representation. For example, the Chhetri caste accounted for 16.6% of the population initially but decreased to 15.3% by September 2014 ![Chhetri caste decreased from 16.6% to 15.3%](image4). Other castes and ethnic groups also experienced minor changes, though the overall structure remained largely stable. These variations suggest gradual demographic shifts, possibly due to migration or social mobility.

In summary, the rural-urban distribution remained unchanged at 83% rural and 17% urban, while caste/ethnicity showed minor fluctuations, with the Chhetri caste decreasing from 16.6% to 15.3%.

Mobile internet usage activities in Indonesia are deeply intertwined with shopping behaviors, as evidenced by the data and trends. A significant portion of mobile internet activity is driven by social media (24%) and entertainment (20%), which are platforms where users often encounter advertisements and promotions, influencing their shopping decisions [image2]. 

E-commerce traffic in Asia Pacific is heavily dominated by mobile devices, with 3o% of traffic coming from smartphones and tablets. In Indonesia, platforms like lojai.com reported 20% of their sales from mobile devices, while Tokobagus/OLX saw an 8oo% growth in their Android app in 2013 [7]. Social media and instant messaging apps like WhatsApp, BBM, and LINE play a crucial role, as 27% of e-commerce users prefer shopping through IM groups, and 26% through social media [10]. ![Games/apps are the most downloaded mobile content](image2)

Offline and online shopping preferences also highlight the influence of mobile internet. Apparel is the most purchased item both offline (79.2%) and online (67.1%), followed by shoes and bags, indicating a seamless transition of shopping habits from physical stores to mobile platforms [image4]. ![Apparel is the most purchased item both offline and online](image4)

The rise of mobile ads further connects usage and shopping. Intrusive ads like interstitials and off-deck ads are popular, and mobile devices account for 55% of customer decision influence, surpassing TV and desktop [11]. ![Indonesian ad impressions increased significantly over three quarters](image1)

In summary, mobile internet usage in Indonesia fuels shopping behaviors by integrating social media, e-commerce platforms, and targeted ads, creating a dynamic and interconnected digital shopping ecosystem.

The demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia play a significant role in shaping their content preferences and uncovering potential business opportunities. ![The age distribution of mobile internet users shows a strong representation of younger users, with 32% aged 18-24 and 33% aged 25-35](image8). This younger demographic is more likely to engage with mobile content, particularly in areas like social media, entertainment, and gaming. ![Mobile internet activities show social media (24%) and entertainment (20%) as the most popular, followed by general information (16%) and gaming (12%)](image3).

The high engagement with social media is further supported by the fact that 92% of internet users in Indonesia own a Facebook account, and 90% access it through mobile devices [10]. This indicates a strong preference for platforms that facilitate communication and community building, which aligns with instant messaging being the primary method of communication for mobile users [12]. ![The most downloaded mobile content includes games/apps (70%), video (49%), and music (44%)](image3), highlighting the demand for entertainment-based applications.

From a business perspective, these trends suggest opportunities in mobile advertising, e-commerce, and value-added services. For instance, mobile ads are expected to account for 5-10% of the total ads industry by 2015, with intrusive ads like interstitials and off-deck ads being the most popular [5]. Additionally, e-commerce is rapidly growing, with platforms like Tokobagus/OLX seeing an 800% growth in their Android app in 2013 [8]. ![A comparison of offline and online shopping preferences shows apparel as the most purchased item in both categories, with 67.1% online and 79.2% offline](image5). This indicates a robust market for fashion and lifestyle products, which can be further tapped through mobile platforms.

Moreover, the presence of a significant entrepreneurial demographic (16% businessmen and entrepreneurs among mobile internet users) [image8] suggests potential for mobile solutions tailored to small businesses and startups. Services like payment providers and mobile advertising platforms can cater to this segment. ![Payment service providers like Coda Payments and Mandiri e-cash offer solutions for mobile transactions](image6).

In summary, the youthful and tech-savvy demographic of mobile internet users in Indonesia drives a preference for social, entertainment, and gaming content, creating lucrative opportunities in mobile advertising, e-commerce, and business-focused mobile services.

Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat are the top three GSM operators in Indonesia, and their subscriber and data user metrics reflect their dominance in the market. 

![Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat's key metrics compared](image3)  
In 2014, Telkomsel led with 139.3 million subscribers and 63.5 million data users, significantly higher than its competitors. XL followed with 58.3 million subscribers and 32 million data users, while Indosat had 54.2 million subscribers and 29 million data users [3].

![Subscribers and data users for major telecom operators](image6)  
This trend is consistent across years, with Telkomsel maintaining its lead. For instance, in 2013, Telkomsel had 132.7 million subscribers and 60.5 million data users, while XL and Indosat trailed with 68.5 million and 59.7 million subscribers, respectively. XL had 37.5 million data users, and Indosat had 29 million [6].

![GSM dominates the Indonesian telecom market](image4)  
The dominance of these operators is reinforced by the fact that GSM technology occupies 89% of the market, with Telkomsel alone holding a 42% market share as of 2014 [4][5].

In summary, Telkomsel consistently leads in both subscribers and data users, followed by XL and Indosat, reflecting their strong presence in Indonesia’s GSM-dominated telecom market.

From 2013 to 2014, Telkomsel’s subscriber base grew significantly, reaching 139.3 million subscribers, with 63.5 million being data users [6]. This growth can be attributed to the increasing adoption of smartphones and mobile internet usage. ![Telkomsel had the highest number of subscribers and data users compared to other providers](image7)

During the same period, Telkomsel’s ARPU (Average Revenue Per User) likely continued its declining trend, as evidenced by broader industry patterns. ![The ARPU for prepaid services in Indonesia declined from 2008 to 2012, a trend likely continued into 2013-2014](image5) This decline was driven by a combination of factors, including a massive price war initiated by the government, which forced GSM operators like Telkomsel to reduce tariffs [7]. Additionally, the shift from traditional voice and SMS services to data-based communication platforms like instant messaging (IM) and Voice over IP (VoIP) contributed to reduced ARPU from these services [9]. ![Voice and SMS ARPU showed a declining trend from 2013 to 2017, while mobile data ARPU began to rise after 2015](image2)

In summary, Telkomsel’s subscriber base grew due to increased smartphone and data usage, while its ARPU declined due to price wars and the shift toward data-based communication.

Between 2013 and 2014, Telkomsel and XL experienced significant changes in smartphone adoption and ARPU trends. Telkomsel had 35.4 million smartphone users in 2013, while XL had 15 million. The increasing adoption of smartphones led to a shift in user behavior, with more reliance on data-intensive applications like instant messaging and VoIP, reducing the use of traditional voice calls and SMS [4][7]. ![The bar chart shows smartphone users for Telkomsel and XL in 2013.](image3)

This behavioral shift contributed to declining ARPU in voice and SMS services, as highlighted in the line graph showing gradual decreases in Voice and SMS ARPU, while Mobile Data ARPU initially declined but later began to rise as data consumption increased [5][7]. ![The line graph illustrates trends in Voice, SMS, and Mobile Data ARPU from 2013 to 2017.](image1)

Additionally, the competitive landscape played a role, with tariffs hitting rock-bottom and price wars easing, which further stabilized ARPU trends [2][8]. By 2014, Telkomsel and XL continued to focus on increasing smartphone penetration, partnering with vendors to drive adoption, which likely influenced the recovery in data ARPU as users enrolled for larger data plans [3][5]. ![The bar chart compares prepaid ARPU for Telkomsel and XL in 2008 and 2012, showing a decline.](image2)

In summary, smartphone users for Telkomsel and XL grew significantly in 2013, while ARPU for voice and SMS declined due to increased data usage, but data ARPU began to recover as users adopted larger data plans.

Streaming has become the dominant format for music consumption across most genres, but the shares of streaming and album sales vary significantly by genre. 

![Streaming dominates in Latin and R&B/Hip-Hop, while album sales remain strong in Rock and Country](image1)  
The bar chart shows that Latin and R&B/Hip-Hop lead in streaming shares, with 68% and 39% respectively. Meanwhile, Rock and Country retain higher shares of physical album sales, at 32% and 35% respectively. This suggests a cultural or demographic preference for physical formats in these genres.

![Album sales decline overall while streaming experiences explosive growth](image2)  
From 2014 to 2015, streaming equivalent albums (SEA) saw a 91% increase, while physical album sales declined by 6%. This underscores the broader industry shift from traditional album sales to streaming platforms.

![Rock and Country have higher catalog-driven activity, while Pop and R&B/Hip-Hop are more current-driven](image3)  
Rock and Country show higher catalog activity in both album sales (63% and 54%) and streams (82% and 70%), indicating a strong focus on older, classic material. In contrast, Pop and R&B/Hip-Hop are more driven by current releases, particularly in streaming.

![Streaming accounts for 70% of total activity](image4)  
Streaming represents the largest share of total music activity at 70%, far surpassing album sales (51%) and song sales (49%). This highlights the overwhelming preference for on-demand access to music.

![Taylor Swift leads in album sales, while streaming dominates for R&B/Hip-Hop artists](image5)  
Taylor Swift’s album sales account for a significant portion of her total volume, while artists like Drake and Nicki Minaj see a larger share of their sales from streaming, reflecting genre-specific consumption patterns.

In summary, streaming is the leading format across most genres, but Rock and Country still maintain a strong foothold in physical album sales. This suggests that while streaming dominates modern music consumption, traditional formats remain relevant in certain genres, likely due to audience demographics and cultural preferences.

Streaming has emerged as the dominant format in music consumption, contributing significantly to total music activity across genres. ![Streaming is the highest percentage of total music activity at 70%.](image2) However, the contribution of streams varies by genre, as highlighted in genre-specific breakdowns.

Rock, for instance, shows a high catalog share in streaming at 82%, indicating that older Rock tracks remain popular in streaming platforms [10]. ![Rock has the highest streaming catalog share at 82%.](image3) In contrast, Pop music is primarily driven by current releases, with streaming accounting for 58% of its catalog activity [10].

R&B/Hip-Hop and Country also exhibit notable streaming contributions, with 61% and 70% respectively in their catalog shares [10]. ![R&B/Hip-Hop and Country have streaming catalog shares of 61% and 70%.](image3) Latin music, however, stands out with the highest streaming share at 68% in total activity, reflecting its strong presence in digital platforms [5]. ![Latin music has the highest streaming share at 68%.](image5)

Overall, while streaming dominates total music activity, its contribution varies significantly across genres, with Rock, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Latin showing particularly high streaming shares.

The catalog shares of different music formats vary significantly across genres, as shown in the bar graph. ![Catalogs are dominated by Rock for albums and streaming, while Pop leads in song sales.](image1). For instance, **Rock** has the highest catalog share across all formats, particularly in streams at 82%, while **Pop** leads in song sales with 30%. **R&B/Hip-Hop** and **Country** also show strong streaming numbers at 61% and 70%, respectively, but lag behind in album and song sales compared to Rock.

When it comes to albums with the highest on-demand audio stream share, the data from the table highlights notable performers. ![Drake’s "Nothing Was The Same" leads with 47% on-demand audio stream share.](image3). For example, Drake’s *"Nothing Was The Same"* has the highest on-demand audio stream share at 47%, followed by Ariana Grande’s *"My Everything"* at 25%. These figures underscore the growing importance of streaming in the music industry, particularly for genres like R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop.

Rock dominates the music landscape, particularly in album sales, with 37% of album sales and 24% of song sales [1]. However, R&B/Hip-Hop leads in streaming, accounting for 26% of streams, closely followed by Pop and Rock, both at 23% [4]. ![Rock leads in album sales and R&B/Hip-Hop in streaming](image4)

Pop is primarily driven by current releases, while Rock’s strength lies in its catalog, which constitutes 70% of its streaming activity [3]. [7]. ![Rock’s catalog dominates its streaming activity](image7)

Streaming has become the leading format overall, with a 70% share of total activity, while song sales lag at 49% [3]. ![Streaming is the most popular format](image3)

The bar chart "Share of Total Activity" shows Rock at 30%, R&B/Hip-Hop at 21%, and Pop at 17%, with Country and Latin genres trailing at 9% and 5%, respectively [2]. ![Rock is the most popular genre overall](image2)

In terms of specific sales formats, Rock has the highest share of physical album sales at 32%, while Latin music leads in streaming equivalent albums with 68% [5]. ![Latin music dominates streaming equivalents](image5)

Overall, Rock dominates album sales, R&B/Hip-Hop leads in streaming, and Pop is significant in song sales.

The distribution of music sales formats varies significantly across genres, with streaming emerging as a dominant force in several categories. Rock, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Pop lead in overall consumption, but their reliance on different formats differs. Rock dominates physical album sales (32%) and digital albums (26%), while streaming accounts for 26% of its sales. ![Rock leads in physical and digital album sales but streaming is significant](image1). 

In contrast, R&B/Hip-Hop relies heavily on streaming, which makes up 39% of its sales, the highest among the genres. ![R&B/Hip-Hop relies most on streaming](image1). Pop also shows a strong presence in streaming (36%) and track equivalent albums (TEA) at 31%, indicating a preference for single songs over full albums. ![Pop leads in TEA and has significant streaming](image1). Latin music, however, stands out with streaming accounting for a staggering 68% of its total sales, the highest of any genre. ![Latin music is the most reliant on streaming](image1).

Streaming’s dominance is further highlighted in image2, where it represents 70% of total music activity, surpassing album and song sales. ![Streaming leads total music activity](image2). This trend is consistent across genres, as seen in image4, where streaming is the top format for R&B/Hip-Hop (26%) and Pop (23%), while Rock remains strongest in album sales (37%). ![Streaming dominates R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop](image4). 

In summary, R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin music rely most on streaming, while Rock maintains a stronger presence in physical and digital albums.

Rock and R&B/Hip-Hop genres exhibit distinct patterns in music consumption formats, particularly in streaming activities. According to the data, streaming dominates both genres, but the share of catalog content varies significantly. 

![Rock leads in catalog-driven activity across all formats](image4)  
Rock shows a strong catalog presence, with catalog streams accounting for 82% of its total activity. This suggests that Rock fans frequently revisit older tracks, driving a substantial portion of its streaming numbers. 

In contrast, R&B/Hip-Hop has a lower catalog share in streaming at 61%, indicating a stronger focus on current releases. This is further supported by the fact that R&B/Hip-Hop fans are 35% more likely to spend on music annually, including live events and festivals, implying a vibrant engagement with contemporary artists and trends [11].

![Streaming is the leading format for both genres](image7)  
Streaming is the most dominant format for both genres, with Rock at 26% and R&B/Hip-Hop at 39% of Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA). This highlights the shift in consumer behavior toward streaming as the primary mode of music consumption. 

Overall, Rock’s consumption is more catalog-driven, reflecting a preference for established tracks, while R&B/Hip-Hop leans toward current releases, showcasing its dynamic and trendsetting nature.

Streaming and album sales trends vary significantly across music genres, reflecting shifts in consumer behavior and the evolving landscape of the music industry. Rock dominates album sales, with a 32% share of physical albums and 26% of digital albums, while R&B/Hip-Hop leads in streaming, capturing 39% of this format[4]. Pop also performs strongly in streaming, accounting for 36% of streaming equivalent albums, but leans more toward individual song sales, with a 31% share of track equivalent albums[4]. ![Rock leads in album sales, while R&B/Hip-Hop dominates streaming](image4)

Latin music shows a unique pattern, with streaming making up 68% of its total sales, the highest among all genres, while physical and digital album sales are relatively low at 19% and 5%, respectively[4]. Country music, on the other hand, maintains a strong presence in physical album sales (35%) but lags in streaming, which accounts for only 18% of its total sales[4]. ![Latin music has the highest streaming share, while country music excels in physical sales](image4)

The dominance of streaming in genres like R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin reflects the genres' strong appeal among younger, digitally connected audiences. Hip-hop fans, for example, are at the forefront of the digital music movement, spending 35% more annually on music and significantly more on streaming services[3][5]. ![Hip-hop fans drive digital music consumption](image5)

These trends have profound implications for the music industry. Streaming's growth has shifted revenue models, emphasizing access over ownership and favoring genres with strong digital appeal. Artists and labels in streaming-dominant genres may focus more on single releases and playlist placements rather than full albums. Conversely, genres like rock, with a strong album sales base, may continue to benefit from catalog-driven sales[8][11].

![Streaming has become the largest share of the music business](image5) ![Rock is driven by catalog sales, while streaming favors current releases](image8)

In summary, streaming is the leading format overall, but its impact varies by genre, with R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin thriving in this space while rock and country maintain stronger album sales. This divergence suggests a fragmented industry where strategies must be tailored to genre-specific consumption patterns.

Streaming and album sales vary significantly across different music genres, with distinct patterns in current and catalog activities. Rock, for example, is heavily driven by catalog activity, with streams accounting for 82% of its total catalog share, while album sales remain significant at 63%[8]. ![Rock's streaming dominates its catalog share, while album sales remain strong.](image2) In contrast, Pop is more current-driven, with streams making up 58% of its catalog share, but album sales are much lower at 21%[8]. ![Pop's streaming is higher than album sales, reflecting a focus on current hits.](image2)

R&B/Hip-Hop shows a balanced mix, with streams at 61% and album sales at 46% of its catalog share, indicating strong catalog activity in both formats[8]. ![R&B/Hip-Hop maintains a steady balance between streaming and album sales.](image2) Country music follows a similar trend, with streams at 70% and album sales at 54%, reflecting a strong catalog presence[8]. ![Country music has high streaming and album sales shares in its catalog.](image2)

When examining total activity, streaming dominates across most genres, as seen in the bar chart where streams account for 70% of total activity, compared to 51% for album sales[5]. ![Streaming is the leading format across all genres in total activity.](image5) This trend is further supported by the fact that streams are 70% catalog-driven, while album sales are evenly split between current and catalog[12]. 

In summary, streaming is the dominant format across genres, particularly for catalog activities, while album sales remain significant but are often outpaced by streaming, especially in genres like Pop and R&B/Hip-Hop.

The querying criteria that generally yield the worst label diversity across all datasets are those that exhibit strong selection bias toward specific classes, often ignoring minority classes. Empirical evidence from the quotes and images highlights this behavior in strategies such as **VAAL (Variational Adversarial Active Learning)**, **Margin**, and **Entropy** [1][4][6][7]. For example, in the **OrganAMNIST** dataset, VAAL favors the femur-right and platelet classes while neglecting the lung, liver, and monocyte classes [6]. Similarly, on the **PathMNIST** dataset, VAAL shows a preference for the muscle class and ignores mucus and mucosa, resulting in lower entropy and less balanced class distribution compared to the **Random** strategy [7]. 

This bias is further corroborated by Table 2 in the text, where these strategies often fail to sample at least one data point for each class, especially in low-budget scenarios [9]. Visual evidence from `![VAAL shows preference for specific classes, ignoring others](image1)` and `![VAAL has lower label diversity compared to Random](image7)` reinforces the observation that VAAL and similar strategies perform poorly in terms of label diversity. 

In summary, **VAAL, Margin, and Entropy** are the querying criteria that yield the worst label diversity due to their tendency to favor majority classes and ignore minority ones.

The system generates a response to the user’s request through a series of sequential steps involving natural language understanding, dialogue state tracking, and policy-based decision-making. Here’s how it works:

![The end-to-end task-oriented dialogue system processes user input through components like utterance encoding, dialogue state tracking, and a policy network to generate a natural language response.](image6)

1. **User Input**: The user provides a natural language request, such as "Movie for the day after tomorrow, please." This input is the starting point for the dialogue.

2. **Utterance Encoding**: The user’s utterance is encoded into a continuous vector using a bidirectional LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) network. This representation captures the semantic meaning of the user’s request [2].

3. **Dialogue State Update**: The encoded user utterance, along with the encoding of the previous system action, is fed into a dialogue-level LSTM. This updates the dialogue state, maintaining a continuous representation of the conversation. The dialogue state includes slots and values representing the user’s goals, such as "date=Thursday" [10].

4. **Dialogue State Tracking**: The system tracks and estimates the user’s goal by maintaining a probability distribution over candidate values for each goal slot. For example, it identifies that the user is asking about a movie on a specific date [10].

5. **Knowledge Base Query**: Based on the updated dialogue state, the system formulates a symbolic query to retrieve relevant information from an external knowledge base. The query results are then encoded for further processing [7].

6. **Policy Network**: The policy network takes the dialogue state, slot value logits, and query results as inputs. It determines the next system action, such as requesting additional information (e.g., "What time do you prefer?") [12].

7. **Natural Language Generation**: Finally, the system uses a template-based natural language generator (NLG) to convert the system action into a natural language response. The response incorporates values from the dialogue state or knowledge base, ensuring it is contextually appropriate [6].

![The policy network processes inputs from the dialogue state and query results to select the system action, which is then converted into a natural language response.](image1)

This end-to-end process ensures the system can effectively interpret user requests, track dialogue progress, and generate relevant and coherent responses.

As shown in ![Comparison of model scores on math datasets](image3), LLaMA 2-Chat achieves the highest scores across the ASDiv (67.1), SVAMP (69.2), and MAWPS (82.4) datasets, significantly outperforming models like OPT-66B, GPT-J, GPT-3, and Toolformer. When paired with UnifiedQA, RAPTOR’s accuracy rises to **56.6%**, outperforming DPR and BM25 by **2.7% and 6.7%**, respectively [10].

It also outperforms these baselines in BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR metrics by margins ranging from **1.7 to 5.8 points** against BM25 and **0.7 to 2.1 points** against DPR [6].

The SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself from other Visual Question Answering (VQA) datasets through its extensive range of categories, fine-grained entities, and knowledge-intensive responses. It includes 22 categories encompassing a wide variety of real-world entities, such as landmarks, paintings, food, and mammals, totaling 7,568 unique entities [5] ![SnapNTell dataset contains 22 diverse categories with 7,568 unique entities.](image5). Each entity is represented by 10 images and accompanied by 10 knowledge-intensive question-answer pairs, resulting in 75,680 QA pairs and images [10].

Unlike traditional VQA datasets, which often feature simplistic yes/no or choice-based questions, SnapNTell emphasizes entity-centric, knowledge-rich answers. For example, while VQA v2 might ask, "Is the umbrella upside down?" and GQA, "What animal is in the box?", SnapNTell poses questions like "What is the current status of the Mendenhall Glacier?", requiring detailed, specific responses [1] ![SnapNTell emphasizes entity-centric, knowledge-intensive responses compared to simpler VQA datasets.](image1). This approach challenges models to provide deeper, more accurate information about the depicted entities.

Additionally, SnapNTell surpasses other datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA in terms of the number of categories, unique entities, QA pairs, and images. It also features a significantly longer average answer length (25.7 words) and ensures anonymity in its questions [9] ![SnapNTell outperforms ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA in categories, entities, QA pairs, and answer length.](image7).

In summary, SnapNTell stands out by offering a more comprehensive, diverse, and knowledge-driven dataset compared to existing VQA benchmarks, making it a robust tool for evaluating models' ability to recognize entities and generate detailed, accurate responses.

- **BERT-MRC+DL**: F1 score rises to 91.88 (+0.77)  
- **BERT-MRC+DSC**: F1 score reaches 92.07 (+0.96), the highest among the variations.

Overall, the BERT-MRC+DSC variant consistently outperforms other variations on both datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving model performance.

'Our Approach' demonstrates superior performance on both the LANI and CHAI datasets compared to other methods. For LANI, it achieves a stop distance (SD) of 8.43 and task completion (TC) accuracy of 36.9, which are the best results among the evaluated methods [1]. ![Performance comparison of methods on LANI and CHAI datasets](image1) Similarly, on CHAI, 'Our Approach' achieves an SD of 3.34 and manipulation accuracy (MA) of 39.97, again outperforming competitors like CHAPLOT 18 and MISRA 17, which fail to learn on CHAI [1]. Additionally, in goal prediction metrics, 'Our Approach' excels with a distance (Dist) of 8.67 and accuracy (Acc) of 35.83 for LANI, and Dist of 2.12 and Acc of 40.3 for CHAI, further confirming its effectiveness [1]. ![Comparative results of different methods on LANI and CHAI datasets](image1) This performance improvement is attributed to the model’s decomposition into goal prediction and action generation, which allows for tailored learning methods and better interpretability [4][8]. Overall, 'Our Approach' consistently outperforms baseline and previous methods across both datasets.

In summary, the **CCNN+WLSTM+CRF** model, leveraging character-level CNN features and word-level LSTM, achieves the highest F1-value for NER.

Training NLP models can result in substantial CO₂ emissions, often comparable to everyday activities like air travel or even annual carbon footprints. For instance, training the BERT model on GPUs emits CO₂ emissions roughly equivalent to a trans-American flight, which is 1,984 lbs of CO₂e [4]. 

![A trans-American flight emits 1,984 lbs of CO₂e](image5)

In comparison, training a single NLP model like GPT-2 can consume significant energy, leading to emissions that are much higher than everyday activities. For example, training a single model can cost between $52–$175 in cloud compute costs, with an electric cost of $5, while scaling up to 24 models can cost $1,238–$4,205 and emit much higher CO₂ [11]. 

![Training 24 models can cost up to $4,205 in cloud compute](image3)

The environmental impact becomes even more pronounced when considering the energy sources used for these computations. For instance, data centers in countries like China rely heavily on coal (65%) for energy, significantly increasing CO₂ emissions [2]. In contrast, companies like Google, which have a higher reliance on renewables (56%), still contribute to emissions due to the sheer scale of energy consumption [2].

![China relies on coal for 65% of its energy](image2)

Overall, the CO₂ emissions from training NLP models are substantial and can rival or exceed those of daily human activities, highlighting the environmental cost of advancing AI technologies. Training NLP models can emit CO₂ equivalent to significant everyday activities like air travel or annual human carbon footprints.

The model with the highest test median score is **BERT (Large)**, achieving a median score of **0.712** [6]. The architecture of BERT is designed to process claims, reasons, and warrants independently. ![BERT processes claims, reasons, and warrants through tokenization and deep layers](image2) The claims and reasons are joined to form the first text segment, which is paired with each warrant and independently processed. The final layer CLS vector is passed to a linear layer to obtain the logits, and the entire architecture is fine-tuned [3]. Additionally, the general architecture involves shared parameters θ that classify each warrant independently with the argument, yielding logits that are concatenated and passed through a Softmax layer for the final prediction [4]. ![The general model architecture processes argument-warrant pairs independently](image1) This design allows BERT to exploit statistical cues efficiently, as demonstrated by its performance metrics [10].

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models varies significantly between the WikiHop and MedHop datasets under the standard and gold chain conditions. 

For **WikiHop**, BiDAF outperforms FastQA in both conditions. Under the standard condition, BiDAF achieves 42.9% accuracy on the test set and 49.7% on the validated test set (test*), while FastQA scores 25.7% and 27.2%, respectively. In the gold chain setup, where only relevant documents are provided, BiDAF’s accuracy improves to 57.9% (test) and 63.4% (test*), whereas FastQA reaches 44.5% and 53.5% [11]. When answers are masked, BiDAF further excels, achieving 81.2% (test) and 85.7% (test*), compared to FastQA’s 65.3% and 70.0% [3].

For **MedHop**, BiDAF also generally performs better. Under the standard condition, BiDAF scores 47.8% (test) and 61.2% (test*), while FastQA lags with 23.1% and 24.5%. In the gold chain setup, BiDAF’s accuracy soars to 86.4% (test) and 89.8% (test*), whereas FastQA achieves 54.6% and 59.2%. With masking, BiDAF’s performance reaches 99.3% (test) and 100.0% (test*), compared to FastQA’s 51.8% and 55.1% [11].

![BiDAF outperforms FastQA on both datasets, with notable improvements in the gold chain and masked settings](image3)  

In summary, BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA on both datasets, especially in the gold chain and masked conditions, demonstrating its superior ability to integrate cross-document information.

The table in **image4** confirms that EED has the highest absolute Pearson correlation value (0.942) for **fr-de**, outperforming other metrics like ESIM (0.942), BLEU (0.864), and chrF (0.864).
